_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EcoElectrica, L. P. Pe?uelas Power Plant and LNG Terminal (EcoElectrica) owns and will operate a Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) marine unloading and storage terminal and a 507 MW combined cycle power plant. The facility is located in the Municipality of Pe?uelas, Puerto Rico. The intent of the facility is to provide the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority (PREPA) with additional electric power.  The LNG stored at the terminal will be vaporized to form natural gas which will be combusted in the power plant combustion turbines.  Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) will be an alternate fuel and low sulfur distillate oil will serve as an emergency backup fuel if LNG or LPG are not available.   The power plant consists of a combined cycle generating module which includes two combustion turbines/generators exhausting into separate heat recovery steam generators (HRSG's).  The HRSG's produce steam that will be routed to a steam turbine /generator and to a desalination plant capable of producing fresh water from sea water.  Other facility processes are a closed cooling water system, a demineralization plant and a remineralization plant to produce potable water for the Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) systems for Pe?uelas and Guayanilla. 

Accidental Release Prevention Program

EcoElectrica will use anhydrous ammonia for the control of NOx emissions generated during combustion processes.  Ammonia will be stored within EcoElectrica premises.  For the potable water system, EcoElectrica will use and store chlorine onsite.  EcoElectrica has the capacity to store chlorine and ammonia (anhydrous) over the RMP threshold quantities (2,500 lb and 10,000lb respectively).

EcoElectrica is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the RMP rule (40 CFR Part 68).  This determination has been made on the following basis:

* As determined in the off-site consequence analysis for chlorine and ammonia, public receptors are within the circle with its center at the point of the release a

nd a radius determined by the distance to the endpoints of chlorine and ammonia, as defined in 40 CFR ?68.22(a); and
* Ammonia and Chlorine processes are also subject to the Process Safety Management Program (PSM) requirements of the 29 CFR ?1910.119.

The Stationary Source and the Substances Handled

Ammonia is stored at the facility in a 15,000 gallons tank.  A maximum of 75,158 pounds of ammonia will be stored at the facility at any given time.

Chlorine will be stored at the facility in a ton container.  A maximum of 2,000 pounds of chlorine will be stored at the facility at any given time, but EcoElectrica has the capacity to store 17 1-ton containers of chlorine.

Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios for Ammonia  

The "worst-case release scenario" for ammonia is assumed to be the release of the entire contents of the storage tank, over a period of ten (10) minutes, due to a tank rupture . The largest amount of ammonia in the tank at any given time is 75,158 pounds. The toxic endpoint for ammonia is 0.14 mg/L.  

The analysis for ammonia was made taking into consideration the topography, which was determined to be rural and any passive mitigation, such as dikes or enclosures. EcoElectrica does not have these types of mitigation systems for the ammonia storage area.

The maximum distance to the endpoint was determined to be 4.9 miles using the RMP CompTM Program.  This scenario is based on an assumed wind speed of 1.5 meters/second (3.4 miles/hour), Class F stability, and an air temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit at 50 percent relative humidity.  

Several public receptors are located within this distance, including residences, two schools (Escuela Mario Mercado, located at approximately 3.5 miles NW of EcoElectrica and Escuela Segunda Unidad, located approximately 2.8 miles NE of EcoElectrica), industrial buildings, and some recreational areas. Guanica State Forest (Bosque Estatal de Guanica) is also located within this distance. The estimated popula

tion contained within this circle is 32,000 persons.  This is based on 1990 Census data obtained from the LandView(R) III program. 

The "alternative release scenario" for anhydrous ammonia is assumed to be the release of ammonia through a safety valve that due to overpressure of the 2inch internal diameter pipe used to fill the anhydrous ammonia container, releases anhydrous ammonia for a period of 10 minutes, over rural topography. The topography determination was based on the few buildings and other obstructions (e.g., trees) in the area where the ammonia process is located. The maximum distance to the endpoint was determined to be 0.5 miles using the RMP Compa Program.  This scenario is based on an assumed wind speed of 3.0 meters/second (6.7 miles/hour), Class D stability, and an air temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit at 50 percent relative humidity.  Appendix B contains the RMP Compa Program summary for this scenario.

The estimated population contained within this circle is 140 persons.  This is based on 1990 Census data obtained from the LandViewa III program and U.S.G.S. Maps.  A complete summary of the LandViewa III data is contained in Appendix C.  No environmental receptors are located within this distance.
 
Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios for Chlorine

The "worst-case release scenario" for chlorine is assumed to be the release of the entire contents of the tank, over a period of ten (10) minutes due to a tank rupture.  The largest amount of chlorine in each container at any given time is 1 ton or 2,000 pounds. The toxic endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L.  

The analysis for chlorine was made taking into consideration the topography, which was determined to be rural and any passive mitigation, such as dikes or enclosures. EcoElectrica does not have these types of mitigation systems for the chlorine storage area.

The maximum distance to the endpoint was determined to be 3.0 miles using the RMP CompTM Program.  This scenario is based on

an assumed wind speed of 1.5 meters/second (3.4 miles/hour), Class F stability, and an air temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit at 50 percent relative humidity.  

Several public receptors are located within this distance, including residences, one school (Escuela Segunda Unidad, located approximately 2.8 miles at the NE of EcoElectrica), some recreational areas, and industrial buildings.  The estimated population contained within this circle is 9,500 persons.  This is based on 1990 Census data obtained from the LandView(R) III program. No environmental receptors are located within this distance.

The "alternative release scenario" for chlorine is assumed to be a leaking 3/8 inch internal diameter flexible connection tubing used to connect the chlorine container to the chlorine piping system.  The maximum distance to the endpoint was determined to be 0.7 miles using the RMP CompTM Program.  This scenario is based on an assumed wind speed of 3.0 meters/second (6.7 miles/hour), Class D stability, and an air temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit at 50 percent relative humidity.  

Several public receptors are located within this distance, including industries at the north part of the chlorine storage area.  The estimated population contained within this circle is 270 persons.  This is based on 1990 Census data obtained from the LandView(R) III program.  No environmental receptors are located within this distance.

Five-year Accident History

EcoElectrica is a new facility.  At this time, no flammable nor toxic substances were present, therefore no accident history is available for the chlorine or ammonia processes.

Emergency Response Program
  
EcoElectrica is responsible for developing and maintaining an effective Emergency Response Plan.  The following tasks are part of EcoElectrica's Emergency Response Plan:

1.  Recognize the existence of an emergency condition.
2.  Notify appropriate plant personnel and off-site authorities of the existence of an emergency condit

ion.
3.  Take corrective actions to alleviate the severity of the emergency.
4.  Request additional support as deemed necessary.
5.  Establish and maintain effective communications within the Plant and with off-site response groups.
6.  Continuously assess the status of the emergency situation and communicate that status to the appropriate groups and agencies.
7.  Provide timely and accurate information to the public through the media in conjunction with local officials, if required.
8.  Take protective measures on-site for employees and property.
9.  Notify appropriate Plant personnel and off-site authorities of the return to normal conditions.

For any emergency situation involving Ammonia or Chlorine, The National Response Corporation will provide EcoElectrica with an emergency response team for rapid and effective response to the accident.  The contact person at the National Response Team Corporation is:
